Award.AwardTitle: DMREF: Analysis and Optimization of Polymer Networks for Emerging Applications
Award.AbstractNarration:
In this project funded by the Designing Materials to Revolutionize and Engineer our Future program of the Chemistry Division, Jeremiah Johnson and Bradley Olsen from Massachusetts Institute of Technology will develop methods for the synthesis and characterization of dynamic polymer networks. The research project involves a closely integrated collaboration between experimental work and computational studies to develop a technique for the quantitative analysis of defects in polymer networks. Novel polymer network materials with dynamic crosslinks and isotopic labeling will be synthesized and their defect contents will be characterized as a function of the synthetic conditions. New theoretical and computational methods will be developed for the analysis of network structure and correlated with the experimental results. The broader impacts of the project involve the potential technological benefits of better understanding the structure of polymer network materials, training graduate and undergraduate students in interdisciplinary science, enhancing research infrastructure through the establishment of strong collaborations between experiment and theory groups, and developing hands-on teaching modules on polymer gels aimed at middle school students.

Hydrogels are networks of long chain molecules that can absorb up to 99% of their weight in water, and they are important materials for a number of consumer products and biomedical technologies. Structural defects in the network are key contributors to limitations on the performance of hydrogel materials. This research project seeks to develop experimental and theoretical strategies for identifying and counting the number of defects in the networks. Such information will permit the preparation of hydrogels with fewer defects and superior properties and could lead to novel materials for biomedical technologies and water purification membranes, amongst many applications.

POR.DRECONTENT:
This program focused on understanding and controlling defects in polymer networks. As a key experimental advance, we devised a new method called Network Disassembly Spectrometry (NDS) that allowed us to count the number of topological loop defects in networks of crosslinked polymers.  With information made possible by this advance, we devised a scheme to quantify how defects impact the elastic modulus of a rubbery material, which answers a long-standing question of great relevance to polymer science and engineering. Elasticity is one of the most fundamental and important properties of matter, and elastic “rubber” materials are ubiquitous in daily life, industry, and modern materials research. Rubber materials are interconnected networks of individual polymer molecules (“macromolecules”), and researchers had long speculated that topological defects in these networks (for example, macromolecules that connect to themselves instead of to other macromolecules) would impact the elasticity of rubber materials; however, it was deemed impossible to know for sure because these defects, which are only a few billionths of a meter in size, were buried within the complex network. Through an unprecedented chemical labeling strategy, we synthesized a new class of polymer networks that provided the first exact measurements of topological defects in rubbery networks. Using these materials, we produced a quantitative and predictive model of elasticity — Real Elastic Network Theory — that addresses the textbook challenge of how molecular defects impact elasticity, and could find broad use in the design of elastic materials in industrial and academic applications. Furthermore, this program led to advances in so-called "dynamic covalent networks" based on photo-responsive materials and metal-coordinated networks.  Such materials could find applications in sensing, filtration, 3D printing, and tissue engineering.

 


Last Modified: 10/10/2016
Modified by: Jeremiah Johnson
